Directions: The answer to the following question is a single-digit integer, ranging from 0 to 9.

If f(x) = ({x} – 1)2, x ∈ [– 3, 4] (where {.} is f.p.f.), then find the number of points of discontinuities of f(x).

Directions: The answer to the following question is a single-digit integer, ranging from 0 to 9 .
\(\begin{array}{l}\text { Find the number of integral points of continuity of } f ( x )=\left\{\begin{array}{c}\sin \left(\frac{\pi}{4}( x \}\right), \\ \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{4}(1-\{ x \}),[ x ]\right. \text { is even }\end{array}\right. & \text { on }(0,4), \text { where }[.] \text { denotes }\end{array}\) g.i.f. and \(\{.\}\) denotes f.p.f.
The set of all points where the function \(f(x)=\sqrt{1-e^{-x^{2}}}\) is differentiable is

q_option: The function is discontinuous at x = 1.
The function is continuous at x = 1.
The function is discontinuous at x = 0.
The function is not differentiable at x = 0.
1.q_string: If \(f(x)=\left[\sqrt{2-x^{2}}\right](\) where \([.]\) is g.i.f.), then which of the following statements is/are wrong?

q_option: f(x) is continuous as well as differentiable everywhere.
f(x) is continuous everywhere, but not differentiable at x = 4.
f(x) is neither continuous nor differentiable at x = 4.
